input:
Text: Realistically no domestic company is going to touch the stuff. You haven’t been able to get liability insurance for asbestos containing products since the 1990s and even a whiff of the stuff in your product will get you sued to oblivion. The asbestos litigation is a behemoth and will come for and bankrupt via legal fees any company that tries to use any fiber in their product nowadays. And because it’s mostly state tort claims federal EPA approval doesn’t provide a realistic defense.
Aspects: asbestos litigation

You haven’t been able to get liability insurance for asbestos containing products since the 1990s and even a whiff of the stuff in your product will get you sued to oblivion. The asbestos litigation is a behemoth and will come for and bankrupt via legal fees any company that tries to use any fiber in their product nowadays. And because it’s mostly state tort claims federal EPA approval doesn’t provide a realistic defense.
Aspects: any company

input:
Text: Thinking that nuclear power plants will have a positive impact over the next 20 years is not the same as supporting nuclear energy. It is absolutely possible to think nuclear is good short term but that the cost of monitoring and storing the nuclear waste for centuries or millenia to come makes it a net negative long term. It's also possible to support nuclear but think that nuclear will be a net negative short term because only the next generation of fission or fusion powerplants that come online in the 2045+ will be truly positive.
Aspects: fission or fusion powerplants

Text: The energy sector is probably the only thing I can be proud of my home province of NB for lol. The Belledune coal plant is on track to be shut down. Depending on the day 60-75% of New Brunswick's power already comes from renewable or non-emitting nuclear generation. The province is investing in small modular nuclear reactors and is already planning to add one to the grid at Point Lepreau. It's probably the only province with any realistic change of going completely green by 2030.

The energy output compared to the amount of material input used for fission is as far as my basic knowledge knows if wrong please corrrect unmatched. It’s clean energy it’s just a matter of responsibly containing the waste. BTW Toxic waste barrels aren’t filled with green goo like everyone thinks it’s just compressed radiation suits and other dry material encased in concrete.
Aspects: Nuclear

Nuclear waste is nothing compared to the increased rates of lung cancer etc caused by fossil fuels.

input:
Text: What happens when we run out of fissionables ? I've read alternatingly sunny and dismal reports of the economic and ecological impacts of nuclear technology but I've read no report on either side of the issue which presents a very sunny prognosis for the long-term viability of nuclear energy. Sooner or later all fissile material is non-renewable and all are comparatively scarce elements in the Earth's crust. If the long-term energy destiny of the human species is renewable energy then what is the merit of diverting into an energy source we know to be a cul-de-sac ?
Aspects: fissionables

Text: Important points The review’s lead author Prof Bill Bateman of Curtin University said the research did not intend to be “censorious” but aimed to raise awareness of the environmental impacts of man’s best friend with whom humans’ domestic relationship dates back several millennia. ... Although we’ve pointed out these issues with dogs in natural environments … there is that other balancing side which is that people will probably go out and really enjoy the environment around them – and perhaps feel more protective about it – because they’re out there walking their dog in it.
Aspects: man’s best friend

Text: Important points The review’s lead author Prof Bill Bateman of Curtin University said the research did not intend to be “censorious” but aimed to raise awareness of the environmental impacts of man’s best friend with whom humans’ domestic relationship dates back several millennia. ... Although we’ve pointed out these issues with dogs in natural environments … there is that other balancing side which is that people will probably go out and really enjoy the environment around them – and perhaps feel more protective about it – because they’re out there walking their dog in it.
Aspects: walking their dog

Text: The Biden administration has surpassed the $100bn mark in clean energy grants through the Inflation Reduction Act IRA . The milestone has been confirmed by John Podesta Biden’s senior advisor for international climate policy as reported by Reuters. The administration aims to solidify clean energy deployment before President-elect Donald Trump who plans to rescind unspent IRA funds takes office. “Crossing the milestone of $100bn awarded shows just how quickly we’re getting these funds out the door and into communities so they can make a real difference for the American people ” Podesta told Reuters.
Aspects: $100bn awarded

Text: The following submission statement was provided by --- From the article: The UK closed its last remaining coal power plant as the country marked a definitive swing toward clean energy. Nottinghamshire’s Ratcliffe-on-Soar Power Station which had powered the nation for 57 years officially stopped generating electricity. This event signals the end of Britain’s 142-year reliance on coal dating back to 1882 when the world’s first coal-fired power station opened in London. The country will also become the first G7 nation to eliminate coal-fired power production. Phil MacDonald managing director of global energy think tank Ember captured the significance of the moment “This is the final chapter of a remarkably swift transition from the country that started the Industrial Revolution.” The closure also aligns with the UK’s government policy to phase out coal a plan that was set in motion almost a decade ago. --- Please reply to OP's comment here:
Aspects: final chapter

input:
Text: It's more expensive and no more convenient than the supermarket. I can get an entire week's shopping delivered from the supermarket it really makes little sense to still use a milkman. I think we're 'environmentally aware' until it becomes costly or inconvenient. Just look at the rise of Shein Temu etc. Everyone knows what awful companies they are and that their products are made from questionable materials but it's cheap and available at the click of a button. Charity shops are an environmentally friendly alternative they are cheap but not convenient. Then there are 'slow fashion' brands which are convenient but not cheap. That being said I actually do use a milkman and have for the past 6ish years. I only signed up because someone came to my door offering it and I liked the nostalgia of it. The cost really racks up but I like supporting the local dairy so I've kept it. Served me well during covid too.
Aspects: Shein Temu

Text: Nuclear energy produces electricity not gas and 50% of german heating is gas heating. So the gas heating problem in winter cannot be covered by nuclear power. The demand for electricity is covered in germany it is just the distribution that is lacking. input:
Text: As others have said nuclear from a climate change perspective is excellent. Very expensive though. As long as the reactor design is not around producing weapon grade material they exist so much the better. And there is a waste issue but compared to the waste issue with fossil fuels it’s fairly manageable. However slow to build at least 10 years to build after approvals are in place … some are nudging 20 years of build . So given where we are in the journey nuclear is largely “too late”.
Aspects: nuclear from a climate change perspective

Text: Oh dear. The infrastructure isn't there yet. It makes sense in the long run but just shutting them down before the wind and solar is made is shooting yourself in the foot. Most electric car charging comes from coal. If you shut down the pipeline and shut down coal plants how is anyone gonna charge their car ? If you can't charge and its illegal to buy a gas car how will you travel ? This is just a sound bite to win votes. Until we have the infrastructure for this you can't just shut things down without ppl starving or freezing. And if you are eco minded it will just make ppl have to buy a gas car. It makes no sense to do this until the infrastructure is in place. Insanity.
Aspects: shut things down

input:
Text: To clarify they aren't going to convert the plants themselves by just ripping out the coal boiler und plunging some uranium rods in their place. The plan is to build new modern small nuclear reactors at the sites where coal power plants used to be. The advantage of that is that all the transmission lines and grid infrastructure is already set up to receive electricity from there. I would also imagine that it reduces the NIMBY problem because the people who live close to coal power plants are not the sort who have a lot of money and political influence.
Aspects: small nuclear reactors

input:
Text: Until we convert to nuclear power more electric cars does nothing to impact the environment in a positive way. Instead of fueling up directly at a gas station you'll be "charging up" at a station powered by generators wind farms that fill up landfills with non-biodegradable large fans or solar farms that again fill up landfills with large panels. Text: This is a step in the right direction but unfortunately there's a major practical concern with nuclear. Safe nuclear energy is a complicated business that operates at a large scale. It requires a sophisticated and experienced industrial base to pull off in a cost effective manner. Sadly I don't think such an industrial base now exists in the US and it will take time to build. We definitely can and should incorporate new nuclear power into the US power infrastructure but we should expect cost overruns and delays while we spin up.
Aspects: nuclear energy

input:
Text: This is a step in the right direction but unfortunately there's a major practical concern with nuclear. Safe nuclear energy is a complicated business that operates at a large scale. It requires a sophisticated and experienced industrial base to pull off in a cost effective manner. Sadly I don't think such an industrial base now exists in the US and it will take time to build. We definitely can and should incorporate new nuclear power into the US power infrastructure but we should expect cost overruns and delays while we spin up.
Aspects: US power infrastructure

Text: Ontario closed the last of their coal plants started to refurbish nuclear and built a heck of a lot of solar and wind capacity. Then that government was kicked out partially because of the rising price of electricity. The new one has cancelled multiple nearly completed wind projects dropped the cap and trade program torn out existing car charging stations and cut subsidies to electric cars. Aspects: government

input:
Text: Not to be a party pooper here but the main reason coal plants are closing is the high costs it takes to keep them running with all of the government regulations and that natural gas is really cheap right now. The companies that own them can either spend a ton upgrading these buildings that are likely very old to meet new government standards or just buy/generate their power elsewhere. Natural gas is dirt cheap and will be for the foreseeable future so power companies are going that route. Not that people aren't investing in renewable energy but that has pretty much no connection to coal plants closing down.
Aspects: Natural gas

input:
Text: Title is misleading: this isn't a electric power plant but a thermal power plant used to provide Beijing's urban districts with heat during the winter. So this is like closing down a coal plant in Queens for NYC Chaoyang is Beijing's big NE urban district where I lived for 8 years and of course no American city that I know of provides city-wide central heating. Most of Beijing's actual electricity is probably still coming from coal even if the power stations are located across the border in Hebei. As much of Beijing's air pollution comes in from Hebei this isn't going to solve its AQI problem for next winter but should hopefully improve it.
Aspects: Title

Text: Such a massive power shift may sound impossible to those of us from the United States where giant oil and coal corporations control the energy industry and the very idea of human-caused climate change is still hotly contested. Here in Germany that debate is long over. A dozen years of growing public support have driven all major political parties to endorse the Energiewende. If a member of parliament called climate change a hoax or said that its cause is unknown he or she would be laughed out of office.
Aspects: Energiewende

input:
Text: I work for a company that builds industrial gas and steam turbines in the americas. We have projected decrease in coal use regardless of who is president. The projections come from surveying power companies among other things. No power company is planning to build coal plants. It's nearly all renewable or natural gas. They all anticipate the long term regulations over 25+ years to generally be unfavorable for coal. The companies have to consider this because the plant must operate for that long. No short term change by any president is going to swing them one direction or the other. Also new power plants are planned more than 4 years in advance anyway. So any change might come too late for voters hoping to see an increase in coal usage by the next election. They only thing Trump can do for coal is temporarily slow the rate that the coal plants are being closed down.
Aspects: long term regulations

input:
Text: I personally think what you're highlighting is not a flaw of how rangers are designed but instead a flaw of how DnD is designed or at least how the game is limited by design choices. How you describe rangers may be their ideal role in a party but mechanically 5e does not do enough to facilitate such a role. Environmental awareness and scoping out a battle before it starts are very simple mechanics and there's not enough there to build an entire class around. I'm not saying I have the solution but one thought is that there needs be more emphasis between running into a battle and **approaching** a battle. Rangers essentially need to be given foresight on how the first round or two of battle will play out based on enemy composition and environment and have feats that allow them to respond appropriately. But once again this would necessitate a phase of gameplay that is between out-of-combat and in-combat that is way more fleshed out than what we currently have.
Aspects: how rangers are designed

input:
Text: This is very misleading. They are not counting the plants that make renewable products. They are not counting the shipping of those things. They are not counting -- it goes on and on. Edit- okay-- the more-- running a deficit economy means borrowing- the future will have carbon costs to pay off that deficit. -- running homes colder means more deaths from the flu. running public spaces colder means more deaths from the flu. forcing public works to close viable amortized coal plants means losses accrue onto the public purse. subsidizing dispappointing pseudo-renewables means that some other source pays that-- that source is not in Rivendale- all outlays are paid for in the hydrocarbon economy. having power 3 times more expensive than your competition has consequences- are you sure its saving the planet ?
Aspects: forcing public works to close viable amortized coal plants

Aspect: Putting the onus on individuals to “solve” climate change
instruction: 你是一個情緒回歸模型。請讀取輸入文本，並針對指定的 Aspect（目標）預測 Valence-Arousal（V-A）分數。Valence（V）：衡量正面或負面的程度；Arousal（A）：衡量平靜或興奮的程度。分數範圍 1.00–9.00，保留兩位小數。1.00 表示極度負面效價或極低喚醒度；9.00 表示極度正面效價或極高喚醒度；5.00 表示中性效價或中等喚醒度。請以字串格式「V#A」呈現，並只輸出 JSON：{"Aspect_VA":[{"Aspect":"...","VA":"V#A"}]}。
input:
Text: Putting the onus on individuals to “solve” climate change will never work. Consumerism will never solve it. Me using 1 ply vs 2 ply or reusing my pasta water to water my plants will not solve climate change. Use a cup if you want to. Use tampons or pads or the special underwear or whatever. It literally will not make a difference. The only thing that will reduce climate change is actually forcing companies to use more sustainable methods of production via heavy and strictly enforced taxation. Period.
Aspects: Putting the onus on individuals to “solve” climate change

Text: Arguably the proliferation of charging stations will make more of a difference in rate of EV adoption than the additional tax rebate on purchase.
